<div class='col-md-9'>
<p class='lead'> This section provides general information about the `data.table` project. </p>
# data.table project{.page-header #welcome}

<p class='lead'> `data.table` is an R package that enables fast<span class='text-success'> subset</span>, fast<span class='text-success'> grouping</span>, fast<span class='text-success'> assign</span>, fast<span class='text-success'> ordered joins</span> and<span class='text-success'> list columns</span> all in a short flexible syntax, for faster development. </p>
<!-- Operations using data.table -->
<div class='bs-docs-section'>
### Operations using data.table {#dt-operations}

<p > Here's a broad summary of the type of operations you can perform with `data.table`. </p>
```{.r}
DT[X]                           # fast join for large data, DT and X are data.tables
DT[, sum(b*c), by=a]            # fast aggregation, a, b and c are column names.
DT[i, b := 3.14]                # add new column (or modify existing column) by reference
DT[, p := x/sum(x), by=grp]     # fast sub-assignment (to column b) by reference.
fread("big.csv")                # is 3+ times faster than read.csv(, colClasses, nrow, etc).
```
### Comparison to base R {#vs-base}

```{.r}
10+ times faster than tapply              # Fast grouping
100+ times faster than ==                 # Fast binary search based subset
500+ times faster than DF[i, j] <- value  # Fast assignment by reference using := or set
```
<p > For detailed information about timings, checkout the [benchmarks]() section. </p>
</div>
<!-- Installation -->
<div class='bs-docs-section'>
# Installation {#install .page-header}

<p class='lead'> In `data.table`'s development cycle, all even numbered releases (`1.8.10`, `1.9.0` etc..) are stable versions available on CRAN. Similarly, all odd numbered releases are development versions. </p>
### Stable version {#stable}

<p > The current stable release is [1.9.2 on CRAN](http://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/data.table/index.html), released 27<sup>th</sup> Feb 2014. To install, open an R-session and type: </p>
```{.r}
install.packages("data.table")
```
### Development version {#devel}

<p > The current development version is [1.9.3 on Github](https://github.com/Rdatatable/data.table). You can stay up-to-date by following the [latest NEWS](https://github.com/Rdatatable/data.table/blob/master/NEWS) as well as [known bugs and feature requests](https://github.com/Rdatatable/data.table/issues?direction=desc&sort=updated&state=open). If you're interested in testing out the recent commits from the development version, you can install it easily. </p>
```{.r}
devtools:::install_github("datatable", "Rdatatable")
```
</div>
<!-- How to get started? -->
<div class='bs-docs-section'>
# How to get started? {.page-header #get-started}

<p > We suggest that you start by going through the [Beginners FAQ]() first followed by the [10 minute quick introduction]() guide. Once you finish those, you should be fairly familiar with the most essential<span class='text-info'> data.table</span> concepts. You can then dive right in to the [Learn by example]() section and read rest of the [FAQs](), in whichever order you prefer. </p>
</div>
<!-- Getting help -->
<div class='bs-docs-section'>
# Getting help {.page-header}

### Stackoverflow {#stackoverflow}

<p > Stackoverflow's [data.table tag](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/r+data.table) is an excellent place to get started. You can search if your question has already been answered, and if not, you can post a question [with a nice reproducible example](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/5963269/how-to-make-a-great-r-reproducible-example) there. At the time of writing, **93.7%** of the questions under the<span class='text-info'> data.table</span> tag have answers. </p>
### Mailing list {#mailing-list}

<p > Another place to ask questions is the [data.table mailing list](https://r-forge.r-project.org/mail/?group_id=240). It requires a *subscription*, which is fairly straightforward. Once you've subscribed to the mailing list, you can start posting by sending an email to **datatable-help @ lists.r-forge.r-project.org**. </p>
<p > You can browse the questions asked previously on the mailing list on [Nabble](http://r.789695.n4.nabble.com/datatable-help-f2315188.html), [Gmane](http://dir.gmane.org/gmane.comp.lang.r.datatable), [HTML archive](http://lists.r-forge.r-project.org/pipermail/datatable-help) or [RSS feed](http://rss.gmane.org/gmane.comp.lang.r.datatable). </p>
</div>
<!-- contribute -->
<div class='bs-docs-section'>
# How can I contribute? {.page-header #contribute}

<p class='lead'> There are several ways in which you can contribute to the `data.table` project. </p>
<p > If you come across an unexpected behaviour, and you're quite sure of it, then you can <a href="https://github.com/Rdatatable/data.table/issues?direction=desc&sort=updated&state=open">file a bug</a>. It is so much better if the report has a minimal reproducible example along with the output from `sessionInfo()`, although we understand that this may not be possible in *all* cases. </p>
<p > If you're unsure as to whether it's a<span class='text-danger'> **bug**</span> or not, then it might be better to verify it by posting it as a question either on [stackoverflow](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/r+data.table) or on the [data.table mailing list](https://r-forge.r-project.org/mail/?group_id=240). Check the <a href="#get-help">Getting help</a> section for more info on posting questions. </p>
<p > Likewise, if you'd like a particular<span class='text-danger'> **feature**</span> implemented, then you can file a <a href="https://r-forge.r-project.org/tracker/?atid=978&group_id=240&func=browse">Feature Request (FR)</a>. We're quite open to new ideas and suggestions from our users. </p>
<p > You can also help us by fixing, suggesting and/or improving ambiguities in the documentation or the website, contributing code to the project in the form of bug fixes or implementing features, adding articles to [data.table gallery]() highlighting use cases of `data.table` etc. You can do all these things through a `pull request`. </p>
<div id='pull-request' class='bs-callout bs-callout-info'>
#### Pull requests: {#pull-request-box}

<p > You can issue a pull request by editing files from within github and pressing *propose file change*. The project members will be alerted for review and merge. </p>
<p > Alternatively, you can also [fork](https://github.com/Rdatatable/data.table) the project, (locally) make your changes, and push commits in your fork and then initiate a `pull request` for project members to review and merge. The Github article ["Using pull requests"](https://help.github.com/articles/using-pull-requests) explains this very well in a step-by-step manner. </p>
</div>
<p class='lead'> And finally, by spreading the word! </p>
</div>
